headline: Promethium
text: In the early 1900s, most of the elements had been discovered, although a few gaps still existed if predictions based on the Periodic Table of Elements were to be believed. One of those gaps belonged to element number 61. This week, we meet the ephemeral element number 61, an element that truly is a "rare earth metal" because it is vanishingly rare on Earth. This element is promethium, atomic symbol Pm. Originally "prometheum" after the Greek legend of Prometheus, who created humans from clay and later stole fire from Zeus and gave it to humans, the official spelling of this element's name was changed to end with "-ium" by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) to better coincide with the names of the other elements.    All isotopes of promethium are unstable and have short halflives so they are not well characterised. This also makes it very difficult to find photographs of promethium. But I did learn that most promethium salts are pink or red in colour, which makes me wish I could find a picture to share with you.  Currently, a number of different isotopes of promethium are synthesized by bombarding uranium or neodymium with neutrons or are created as a by-product of uranium fission. Naturally-occurring promethium resulting from spontaneous fission of uranium-238 is estimated to comprise roughly 560 g total in Earth's crust at any given time (doi:10.1016/j.nuclphysa.2007.03.001). Promethium is mainly used in research, but even in research labs it is extremely rare. However, I did find one interesting discovery about promethium: it is visible in the emission spectrums of several distant stars, which are formally classified as "peculiar stars" (doi:10.1051/0004-6361:20035726). Since no isotope of promethium has a longer halflife than 17.7 years, this indicates that these stars are actually manufacturing promethium in huge quantities on their surfaces. But how?
